60DDB07BA1544C58BFA5754F72372CD5.description:
Explain how Spanish colonization introduced Christianity, the mission system, and the
encomienda system to the Americas as well as Bartolome de la Casa’s role in the transition
to African slavery.

5DDCB648ACEB4AAC86893E85B44B5262.description:
Explain the impact of the Columbian Exchange on people, plants, animals, technology,
culture, ideas, and diseases among Europe, Africa, Asia, and the Americas in the 15th and
16th centuries, and examine the major economic and social effects on each continent.

1522B3AAB62E453C88CDC70641BF9EA4.description:
Locate and identify the European regions that remained Catholic and those that became
Protestant and how that division affected the distribution of religions in the New World.

1CBA9D730E63446DA2907AD5C66E11CC.description:
Describe how the Aztec and Inca empires were eventually defeated by Spanish
Conquistadors (i.e., Hernan Cortes and Francisco Pizarro).

3F9B54DC8B314212B117526C57768508.description:
Locate and identify French, Spanish, English, Portuguese, and Dutch colonies in the
Americas, and explain how religion impacted the location of settlement by each country.

DFB8DCFBF76C40F0B712CA5551D0DC24.description:
Describe Prince Henry the Navigator’s influence on exploration, voyages, cartographic
improvements, and tools related to exploration (i.e., compass, caravel, astrolabe, and
Harrison’s chronometer) during the Age of Discovery.

E08E756368F1409AB3AA49E1569B163C.description:
Identify the significance of the voyages and routes of discovery of the following explorers by
their sponsoring country: England: Henry Hudson; France: Jacques Cartier; Portugal: Vasco da Gama, Bartolomeu Dias; Spain: Christopher Columbus, Hernando de Soto, Ferdinand Magellan, Amerigo
Vespucci

07053F10C3A0439E8E00515CB63BF7AE.description:
Analyze why European countries were motivated to explore the world, including: religion,
political rivalry, and economic gain (i.e., mercantilism).

89528D6F502E427FBAB3B7667141AA97.description:
Describe the social, economic, and political characteristics of the Maya, Aztec, and Incan
civilizations, including: oral traditions, class structures, religious beliefs, slavery, and
advancements (e.g., astronomy, mathematics, and calendar)

50E1AA3289B54230B2CC47B42AA35B52.description:
Explain the impact of geographic features and climate on the agricultural practices and
settlement of the Maya, Aztec, and Incan civilizations.

C074440FB7F640C69EA292ED8D02AB27.description:
Describe the existence of diverse networks of North American Indian cultures (within present day United States) including: varied languages, customs, and economic and political
structures.

9A119AFE4170488AA754AD7EF9C51909.description:
Explain the impact of geographic features on North American Indian cultures (i.e., Northeast,
Southeast, and Plains), including: clothing, housing, and agriculture

E7442BB3ECF84A4BA0ACEACB8B340DC9.description:
Identify and locate the geographical features of the Americas, including: Andes Mountains; Appalachian; Great Plains; Pacific Ocean Mountains; Gulf of Mexico; Rocky Mountains; Atlantic Ocean; Mississippi River; South America; Caribbean Sea; North America; Yucatan Peninsula; Central Mexican
Plateau

26FDB6E96F91466DA9D0108A9375CEE6.description: Indigenous Civilizations of the Americas: 400-1500s CE

77468458F4E04AD7B8190AEB45394941.description:
Explain the significance of the following in regards to the Scientific Revolution: Sir Francis
Bacon in establishing the scientific method and Sir Isaac Newton’s three Laws of Motion.

93E6850F4EF541749C9D0E57CF190623.description:
Examine Galileo Galilei’s theories and improvement of scientific tools, including the telescope
and microscope.

12E937E90D7744019668C13DE3FE8779.description:
Compare and contrast heliocentric and geocentric theories of the Greeks (geocentric),
Copernicus (heliocentric), and Kepler (elliptical orbits).

775346EC454F43E8AD95373C604829D4.description:
Examine the Golden Age of the Tudor dynasty (i.e., Queen Elizabeth I), including the defeat
of the Spanish Armada and the rise of English power in Europe.

1663FDA0EAC74529BC144F650A0BBB44.description:
Analyze how the Catholic Counter-Reformation emerged as a response to Protestantism and
revitalized the Catholic Church, including the significance of: St. Ignatius of Loyola, the
Jesuits, and the Council of Trent.

939DDB29205E430FA0C9C318BF20DF68.description:
Explain the political and religious roles of Henry VIII and Mary I in England's transition
between Catholicism and Protestantism.

807463745889497E9C66A4829ED7D1BF.description:
Analyze the development of the Protestant Reformation and the split with the Catholic
Church, including: the emphasis on scripture alone, salvation by faith, and predestination.

F5FBF5A0805945AC80B9F0C79932755E.description:
Explain the significant causes of the Protestant Reformation, including: the Catholic Church’s
taxation policies, the selling of indulgences, and Martin Luther’s 95 Theses.

7DC45F12803647C3B9E7210A1BC1CE40.description:
Analyze Johannes Gutenberg’s printing press and William Tyndale’s translation of the Bible
into the English language as vehicles for the spread of books, growth of literacy, and
dissemination of knowledge.

D72ED53D2C5247489D625DAE62647D95.description: Explain the development of Renaissance art, including the significance of: Leonardo da Vinci; Michelangelo; William Shakespeare; Systems of patronage

F408AC85E55B4AE9AACA5B25D43E644B.description:
Explain humanism, and describe how Thomas Aquinas’s writings influenced humanistic
thought and fostered a balance between reason and faith.

94394B2728E04D2BA6F20394C79075AE.description:
Identify the importance of Florence, Italy and the Medici Family in the early stages of the
Renaissance

732B007ED0DD416CAD054E5EBCC20866.description:
Explain how the location of the Italian Peninsula impacted the movement of resources,
knowledge, and culture throughout Italy’s independent trade cities.

0F808DF4071C47D9894FD1F984C12139.description:
Explain the significance of the Reconquista, Inquisition, and the rise of Spanish and
Portuguese kingdoms in the Iberian Peninsula.

38D3A12EC2804F8BB1CCCEF88E64EC88.description:
Describe the significance of the Hundred Years War, including the roles of Henry V in
shaping English culture and language and Joan of Arc in promoting a peaceful end to the
war.

4CA3C12B798843D997A88356299565C1.description:
Analyze the importance of the Black Death on the emergence of a modern economy,
including: Agricultural improvements; A merchant class; Commerce; Technological improvements; Growth of banking; Towns

0D16D1773F934C84B069348027F13EFF.description:
Describe the economic and social effects of the spread of the Black Death (i.e., Bubonic
Plague) from Central Asia to China, the Middle East, and Europe, and its impact on the
global population.

5956A5A150A74D0E89571028DDB39E4C.description:
Explain how the Crusades impacted Christian, Muslim, and Jewish populations in Europe,
with emphasis on the increasing contact with cultures outside Europe.

6747F7D08DB14C5599C58E9E9414C83C.description:
Analyze the causes, effects, and key people of the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd Crusades, including:
Pope Urban II, Saladin, and Richard I.

E4F91298969A401A8979EC4CB045B821.description:
Analyze the impact of the Magna Carta, including: limiting the power of the monarch, the rule
of law, and the right to trial by jury

2AE60C5AB9C446DBA8D58497CCBF2D76.description:
Describe how political relationships both fostered cooperation and led to conflict between the
Papacy and European monarchs.

D7330E821A934FA782E390CD5D39DBDD.description:
Analyze the Battle of Hastings and the long-term historical impact of William the Conqueror
on England and Northern France.

38F566B43D6F4F459966A47AC5337609.description:
Describe the development of feudalism and manorialism, their role in the medieval European
economy, and the way in which they were influenced by physical geography (i.e., the role of
the manor and the growth of towns).

B199EC477B134AAFA4776061AC961960.description:
Explain how Charlemagne shaped and defined medieval Europe, including: his impact on
feudalism, the creation of the Holy Roman Empire, and the establishment of Christianity as
the religion of the Empire.

1A8ACA5C67A141B591227D235CF2C120.description:
Describe the role of monasteries in the preservation of knowledge and spread of the Catholic
Church beyond the Alps.

06B35735BEBC4A21B819203D39176F69.description: Identify and locate geographical features of Europe, including: Alps; Influence of the North Atlantic Drift; Atlantic Ocean; North European Plain; English Channel; Ural Mountains; Mediterranean Sea

6FE09F8CE1254DEE84EC307D72A78E3D.description: Middle Ages in Western Europe: 400-1500s CE

6CFDB14A17E049C094C9EB7670456346.description: Explain the importance of the Malian king Mansa Musa and his pilgrimage to Mecca in 1324

2804620F7A764C2FAD9C1CB9185D28CD.description: Explain the importance of griots in the transmission of West African history and culture.

7847CD49AF7242C9BFFE3D24A0FED7F8.description:
Describe the role of the Trans-Saharan caravan trade in the changing religious and cultural
characteristics of West Africa and in the exchange of salt, gold, and slaves.

DE50F9F640904CBE9DBEF92CFAC001E2.description:
Analyze the growth of the kingdoms of Ghana, Mali, and Songhai, including cities such as
Djenne and Timbuktu as centers of trade, culture, and learning.

C674A3EC47FB44E29CB211C27EB5BE3D.description:
Explain indigenous African spiritual traditions, including: ancestor worship, animism, and the
relationship between humans and deities.

99877D6CF8FF452FB029CE0CE1A6E2CA.description: Identify and locate the geographical features of West Africa, including:  Atlantic Ocean; Niger River; Djenne; The Sahara; Gulf of Guinea; Timbuktu

2F50BCB9D8BE436D8CC4A01788346EE7.description:
Analyze the development of trade routes throughout Asia, Africa, and Europe and the
expanding role of merchants

241FAEF8CD4A4CF1AA3E9C9F4953BF1F.description:
Explain the importance of Mehmed II the Conqueror, the fall of Constantinople, and the
establishment of the Ottoman Empire.

9C0A580B87324A82899FA315A1B9CB90.description: Summarize the contributions of the region’s scholars in the areas of:  Art; Medicine; Geography; Philosophy; Literature; Science; Mathematics

040218861A1E494F918A40F13E93B788.description: Describe the diffusion of Islam, its culture, and the Arabic language.

9BCCB5CBBF914958BC2D2703DF6EAE6E.description: Describe the origins and central features of Islam: Key Person(s): Mohammad; Sacred Texts: The Quran and The Sunnah; Basic Beliefs: monotheism, Five Pillars

1D7BA9DF7CA84E4DA27CBD97A1E21A7B.description: Identify and locate the geographical features of Southwest Asia and North Africa, including: Arabian Peninsula; Euphrates River; Persian Gulf; Arabian Sea; Mecca; Red Sea; Black Sea; Mediterranean; Tigris River; Caspian Sea Sea

E3E41FFC618E4966BA2F176FB6FAB68E.description:
Analyze the importance of regional geography and the location of Constantinople in
maintaining European culture.

71366AC354AD4C6B92B7D9DED2EA6B10.description: Explain the importance of Justinian’s political, social, and architectural achievements.

AFD6B46AD1A74BD181D989231A20306C.description:
Identify the continuation of the Eastern Roman Empire as the Byzantine Empire, and
describe the diffusion of Christianity and the Latin language.

4759EBD80F1E4548BD01D2C31EE352CF.description:
Analyze the rise of a military society in the late 12th century and the role of the shogun and
samurai in Japanese society.

B144185372844AFAA919BF51E7194368.description:
Describe how the Heian aristocracy contributed to the development of a Japanese national
culture.

65FF54CAB7664B0D910201FB34A167C1.description:
Explain how Japanese culture changed through Chinese and Korean influences (including
Buddhism and Confucianism) as shown in the Constitution of Prince Shotoku and the
adoption of the Chinese writing system.

28A2F64D11BC48BEA89EEEE3E97B7CB9.description:
Describe the origins and central features of Shintoism: Key Person(s): None; Sacred Texts: No sacred text; Basic Beliefs: localized tradition that focuses on ritual practices that are carried out
with discipline to maintain connections with ancient past; animism and Kami

2E664781D97C462993B82F09C226D092.description:
Analyze the achievements of the Ming Dynasty and reasons for its isolationism, including
building projects (e.g., the Forbidden City and reconstruction of the Great Wall) and Zheng
He’s sea voyages

E64E6A13FF1A425DBF0CF80A60EEA6C9.description:
Summarize the effects of the Mongolian empires on the Silk Roads, including the importance
of Marco Polo’s travels on the spread of Chinese technology and Eurasian trade.

3D997E7CDFBA4DFBA7A0D2C49A3413A9.description:
Describe Kublai Khan’s conquest of China, and explain how he was able to maintain control
of the Yuan Empire.

15023C67470F4B509D1221873E3936A4.description: Examine the rise of the Mongol Empire, including the conquests of Genghis Khan

D5E4CA693F6F4B28BE3BD58B7E747E9E.description:
Summarize agricultural, commercial, and technological developments during the Song
Dynasties, and describe the role of Confucianism during the Song.

01395234201743798CCAA55C717B82DD.description:
Describe how the reunification of China prior to the Tang Dynasty helped spread Buddhist
beliefs.

1AEBEA4E2F294C60AB338932A839D5F4.description:
Identify and locate the geographical features of East Asia, including: China, Gobi Desert, Korean Peninsula, Sea of Japan (East Sea), Himalayan, Pacific Ocean, Yangtze River
Mountains, Plateau of Tibet, Yellow River, Japan

FC8216787F344BC7A3FBD9D4642DB20B.description:
World History and Geography: The Middle Ages to the Exploration of the
Americas

9BEE1EABF5BF4E2E9ED46309818D62D8.description:
Develop a geographic awareness by: Using the geographic perspective to determine relationships, patterns, and diffusion across space at
multiple scales (e.g., local, national, global), Determining the use of diverse types of maps based on their origin, structure, context, and validity, Analyzing locations, conditions, and connections of places and using maps to investigate spatial
relationships, Analyzing interaction between humans and the physical environment, Examining how geographic regions and perceptions of regions are fluid across time and space

429FC34E86AF457AB56BAF800BC08DF9.description:
Develop historical awareness by: Recognizing how and why historical accounts change over time, Perceiving and presenting past events and issues as they might have been experienced by the
people of the time, with historical empathy rather than present-mindedness, Evaluating how unique circumstances of time and place create context and contribute to action and
reaction, Identifying patterns of continuity and change over time, making connections to the present

29AB858F2E724B038AFA3B75480B76D2.description: Construct and communicate arguments citing supporting evidence to: Demonstrate and defend an understanding of ideas, Compare and contrast viewpoints, Illustrate cause and effect, Predict likely outcomes, Devise new outcomes or solutions

86CBE4E4B7964DA69413A02193CE7F60.description: Synthesize data from multiple sources in order to: Recognize differences among multiple accounts, Establish validity by comparing and contrasting multiple sources, Frame appropriate questions for further investigation

A9788E16FA474C9DB401214A81C63BE4.description: Critically examine a primary or secondary source in order to: Extract and paraphrase significant ideas and relevant information, Distinguish the difference between fact and opinion, Draw inferences and conclusions, Recognize author’s purpose, point of view, and bias, Assess the strengths and limitations of arguments

3678313ADBEF449BABCFE06D86792645.description:
Collect data and information from a variety of primary and secondary sources, including: Printed materials (e.g., literary texts, newspapers, political cartoons, autobiographies, speeches,
letters, personal journals), Graphic representations (e.g., maps, timelines, charts, photographs, artwork), Artifacts, Media and technology sources
